comments.body:
While I don't think you should use this as it changes the global config, it currently doesn't work as it needs you to set `-proxy_url`, `-proxy_username`, `-proxy_password` as it is expecting those params. I don't think the `choco config set` and `choco config unset` should be used as it is a global setting and users may be unaware that setting this can affect it when they run it locally

Instead I think you should use the explicit proxy settings at runtime as shown here https://chocolatey.org/docs/proxy-settings-for-chocolatey#installing-chocolatey-behind-a-proxy-server. It does have a dependency on a relatively new version of chocolatey but I think the benefits outweigh the negatives here and we can just simply say in the documentation these parameters require version `0.10.4` or newer.

If you feel really adventurous you can try and parse the version and fail if it is older and the proxy params are set.

My concerns are with not using standard parameter names and values for the proxy. I would much rather see **proxy** and **no_proxy** options and the same behavior as other modules (using the system-wide proxy settings, if set). See the **get_url** or **win_get_url** (https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/26612) module options.

Agree with that @dagwieers but I think it is too late to work in the `use_proxy` option, currently these changes work with the currently set system proxy so at least we have the default action there. It shouldn't be too hard to work in the `use_proxy: no` option to disable the system proxy but prefer to leave that for another PR.

Great thing if proxy support can make its way into 2.4 , Thanks @jborean93

Not modifying global chocolatey configuration looks neat too. Support for `--proxy-bypass-list` and `--proxy-bypass-on-local` parameters should be added too.

Reading the docs at https://chocolatey.org/docs/proxy-settings-for-chocolatey#installing-chocolatey-behind-a-proxy-server I realize that with chololatey  0.10.4+ versions, proxy should also work through the use of the following env variables : `http_proxy`, `https_proxy`, `no_proxy` making it easier to work with proxies through ansible than it was before.

Also one question comes to mind, what happens if a proxy is globally set on chocolatey install but we don't want to use one through ansible. (weird improbable case I admit)

I already mentioned this, that's what **no_proxy** is for. Look at the **win_get_url** module. The **proxy_url** parameter should be renamed to **proxy** as that's the standard name used by other modules.
Not an issue for you but we might want to investigate this, I believe it should be ` --ignoredependencies` with the 2nd dash
They all exist and they all work AFAIK. Often chocolatey also has 4 options for the same thing. Bad design IMO I guess they took the "be liberal to what you accept" very serious here.

Ok their docs say otherwise https://github.com/chocolatey/choco/wiki/CommandsReference#how-to-pass-options--switches and all long form options start with `--`. I'll keep an eye on it but I suppose we would have heard from others if it didn't work.
I refrained from cleaning all this up, because that's frowned upon, right ? :-)

Yeah, so I think they started doing it differently in newer releases. But we broke win_chocolatey as well by introducing the `--exact` option. This fails to work for chocolatey older than 0.9.10 :-(

Not sure if we want to fix that (by checking the version ourselves), but if we don't, we should update the docs to state chocolatey 0.9.10+ is required.
Probably something for the next Windows meeting, I don't want to make a decision here without a consensus
